revision.text:
In [[computer graphics]], '''A-buffer''', also known as '''anti-aliased''', '''area-averaged''' or '''accumulation buffer''', is a general hidden surface mechanism suited to medium scale virtual memory computers. It resolves visibility among an arbitrary collection of opaque, transparent, and intersecting objects. Using an easy to compute Fourier window (box filter), it increases the effective image resolution many times over the Z-buffer, with a moderate increase in cost.<ref name=CARP84>{{cite journal |url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.210.5497 |first=Loren |last=Carpenter |authorlink=Loren Carpenter |title=The A-buffer, an Antialiased Hidden Surface Method |journal=Computer Graphics |volume=18 |issue=3 |date=July 1984 |pages=103–108 |accessdate=2014-09-10 |doi=10.1145/964965.808585}}</ref>
The A-buffer method is a descendant of the well known Z-buffer, which provides good quality results in moderate time.
== Uses ==
In 3-D image synthesis system, the balance between the quality and the cost of computation has always been needed. Using a full object-precision visible-surface algorithm at each pixel is expensive. A-buffer method provides moderate quality results in moderate cost of computation.
A-buffer help in using visibility techniques and support all conceivable geometric modeling primitives: polygons, patches, quadrics, fractals, and so forth. It also help to handle transparency and intersecting surfaces (and transparent intersecting surfaces).
== Strategy ==
Carpenter's A-buffer algorithm<ref name=CARP84/> addresses this problem by approximating [[Edwin Catmull|Catmull's]] per-pixel object-precision area sampling<ref>{{cite journal |title=A Hidden-Surface Algorithm with Anti-Aliasing |first=Edwin |last=Catmull |authorlink=Edwin Catmull |url=http://design.osu.edu/carlson/history/PDFs/catmull-zbuffer.pdf |journal=Computer Graphics |volume=12 |issue=3 |pages=6–11 |date=August 1978 |doi=10.1145/965139.807360}}</ref> with per-pixel image-precision operation performed on a sub-pixel grid. Polygons are first processed in scan-line order by clipping them to each square pixel they cover. This result in list of clipped polygon fragments corresponding to each square pixel. Each fragment have 4 by 8 bit mask of parts of the pixel it covers.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Foley |first1=James D. |authorlink1=James D. Foley |last2=Feiner |first2=Steven K. |last3=van Dam |first3=Andries |authorlink3=Andries van Dam |last4=Hughes |first4=John F. |authorlink4=John F. Hughes |date=1995 |title=[[Computer Graphics: Principles and Practice]] in C |edition=2nd |isbn= 0-201-84840-6 |publisher=Addison-Wesley}}</ref>
The bit-mask for a fragment was computed by [[bitwise XOR|xoring]] together masks representing each of the fragment's edges. When all polygons intersecting a pixel have been processed, the area-weighted average of the colors of the pixel's visible surfaces is obtained by selecting fragments in depth-sorted order and using their bit masks to clip those of farther fragments.
The bit masks can be manipulated efficiently with [[Boolean operations on polygons|Boolean operations]]. For example, two fragment bit masks can be added together to determine the overlap between them. The A-buffer algorithm saves only a small amount of additional information with each fragment. For example. It includes the fragment's z extent, but no information about which part of the fragment is associated with these z values. Thus, the algorithm must make assumptions about the sub-pixel geometry in cases in which fragment bit masks overlap in z.

{{see also|Angiosperm Phylogeny Group}}
The '''APG II system''' ('''Angiosperm Phylogeny Group II system''') of plant classification is the second, now obsolete, version of a modern, mostly [[Molecular phylogenetics|molecular]]-based, [[list of systems of plant taxonomy|system of plant taxonomy]] that was published in April 2003 by the [[Angiosperm Phylogeny Group]].<ref name="APGII">Angiosperm Phylogeny Group (2003). [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1095-8339.2003.t01-1-00158.x/abstract An update of the Angiosperm Phylogeny Group classification for the orders and families of flowering plants: APG II.] ''[[Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society]]'' 141(4): 399-436. [[doi: 10.1046/j.1095-8339.2003.t01-1-00158.x]]</ref> It was a revision of the first [[APG system]], published in 1998, and was superseded in 2009 by a further revision, the [[APG III system]].
==History==
APG II was published as: *Angiosperm Phylogeny Group (2003). "An update of the Angiosperm Phylogeny Group classification for the orders and families of flowering plants: APG II". ''[[Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society]]'' '''141'''(4): 399-436. (Available online: [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1095-8339.2003.t01-1-00158.x/abstract Abstract] | [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1095-8339.2003.t01-1-00158.x/full Full text (HTML)] | [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1095-8339.2003.t01-1-00158.x/pdf Full text (PDF)] [[doi: 10.1046/j.1095-8339.2003.t01-1-00158.x]])
Each of the APG systems represents the broad consensus of a number of [[Systematics|systematic]] [[botanist]]s, united in the APG, working at several institutions worldwide.
The APG II system recognized 45 [[Order (biology)|orders]], five more than the APG system. The new orders were [[Austrobaileyales]], [[Canellales]], [[Gunnerales]], [[Celastrales]], and [[Crossosomatales]], all of which were families unplaced as to order, although contained in [[Order (biology)|supra-ordinal]] clades, in the APG system. APG II recognized 457 [[Family (biology)|families]], five fewer than the APG system. Thirty-nine of the APG II families were not placed in any order, but 36 of the 39 were placed in a supra-ordinal clade within the angiosperms. Fifty-five of the families came to be known as "bracketed families". They were optional [[Segregate (taxonomy)|segregates]] of families that could be [[Circumscription (taxonomy)|circumscribed]] in a [[sensu lato|larger sense]].
The APG II system was influential and was adopted in whole or in part (sometimes with modifications) in a number of references. It was superseded 6½ years later by the [[APG III system]], published in October 2009.

{{coord|55|54|33.9|N|37|37|10.0|E|display=title}}
The '''Academy of Foreign Intelligence''' (alternatively known as the '''SVR Academy''',<ref>{{cite news |quote=The foreign arm is today known as the SVR, which is the actual successor of the First Chief Directorate; the Andropov Red Banner Institute, in fact, is now called the SVR Academy. |title=Revealed: The Secret KGB Manual for Recruiting Spies |publisher=''[[The Daily Beast]]'' |first=Michael |last=Weiss |date=December 27, 2017 |access-date=January 2, 2018 |url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-kgb-papers-how-putin-learned-his-spycraft-part-1?ref=home}}</ref> previously known as the '''Yuri Andropov Red Banner Institute''' and the '''Red Banner Institute''')<ref name="Ebon1994">{{cite book|author=Martin Ebon|title=KGB: Death and Rebirth|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kqcM5V3NXVoC&pg=PA185|year=1994|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-275-94633-3|pages=185 |quote=More specialized espionage instructions were provided by the Red Banner Institute, renamed in memory of former KGB chief Yuri Andropov and usually simply called the Andropov Institute.}}</ref> is one of the primary [[espionage]] academies of [[Russia]], and previously the [[Soviet Union]], serving the [[KGB]] and its successor organization, the [[Foreign Intelligence Service (Russia)|Foreign Intelligence Service]]. It was attended by future [[President of Russia|President]] [[Vladimir Putin]] during the 1980s.<ref name="Hutchins2012">{{cite book|author=Chris Hutchins|title=Putin|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4kqWFqR0MPwC&pg=PA40|year=2012|publisher=Troubador Publishing Ltd|isbn=978-1-78088-114-0|pages=40 |quote=But these were the honeymoon days and she was already expecting their first child when he was sent to Moscow for further training at the Yuri Andropov Red Banner Institute in September 1984 [...] At Red Banner students were given a nom de guerre beginning with the same letter as their surname. Thus Comrade Putin became Comrade Platov.}}</ref><ref name="Jack2005">{{cite book|author=Andrew Jack|title=Inside Putin's Russia: Can There Be Reform without Democracy?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OPdcCAAAQBAJ&pg=PT66|date=15 December 2005|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-029336-9|pages=66 |quote=He returned to work in Leningrad's First Department for intelligence for four and a half years, and then attended the elite Andropov Red Banner Institute for intelligence training before his posting to the German Democratic Republic in 1985.}}</ref><ref name="PutinGevorkyan2000">{{cite book|author1=Vladimir Putin|author2=Nataliya Gevorkyan|author3=Natalya Timakova|author4=Andrei Kolesnikov|title=First Person: An Astonishingly Frank Self-Portrait by Russia's President Vladimir Putin|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gcDv5Qww_2AC&pg=PA53|date=5 May 2000|publisher=PublicAffairs|isbn=978-0-7867-2327-0|pages=53 |quote=I worked there for about four and a half years, and then I went to Moscow for training at the Andropov Red Banner Institute, which is now the Academy of Foreign Intelligence.}}</ref>
==Location== The school is located near [[Moscow]], with a main facility north of Chelebityevo and a secondary facility at Yurlovo.<ref name="West2007"/><ref name="Truscott2005">{{cite book|author=Peter Truscott|title=Putin's Progress: A Biography of Russia's Enigmatic President, Vladimir Putin|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2jzf8FsShUgC|year=2005|publisher=Pocket Books|isbn=978-0-7434-9607-0|page=46 |quote=Four and a half years after joining the KGB's First Department in Leningrad, Putin was sent to Moscow for further training at the Andropov Red Banner Institute, which became the Academy of Foreign Intelligence. This was the KGB's elite school for foreign agents, where the USSR's top spies were trained. Located in woods outside Moscow, the Red Banner Institute is isolated and fenced-off with barbed wire.}}</ref>
==History== An earlier iteration of the school was founded in 1938 and first called the '''Special Purpose School''' (''Shkola osovogo naznacheniya'').<ref name="Pringle2015">{{cite book|author=Robert W. Pringle|title=Historical Dictionary of Russian and Soviet Intelligence|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J9RQCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA24|date=29 July 2015|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=978-1-4422-5318-6|pages=24}}</ref> It was renamed the Higher Intelligence School (''VRSh'') from 1948-1968.<ref name="FAS">{{cite web |url=https://fas.org/irp/world/russia/fbis/ForeignIntelligenceService.html#AcademyofForeignIntelligence |title=Foreign Intelligence Service |publisher=[[Federation of American Scientists]] |access-date=January 2, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Haslam2015">{{cite book|author=Jonathan Haslam|title=Near and Distant Neighbours: A New History of Soviet Intelligence|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLOYCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT317|date=24 September 2015|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-101812-1|pages=317 |quote=From 1943 it was called the Intelligence School (RaSh), then, from September 1948, the Higher Intelligence School (VRSh), also known as School 101.}}</ref> It was alternatively known as School 1010 or the 101st School, and referred to as '''K1''' or ''Gridnevka'' by students.<ref name="Pringle2015"/><ref name="West2007"/><ref>{{cite book|title=FBIS Daily Report: Central Eurasia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VtcVAQAAMAAJ|year=1995|publisher=The Service|page=3 |quote=After the war V.V. Gridnev served as director of the 101st School, which trained personnel for our foreign intelligence service. The future intelligence agents idolized their director and informally called the 101st School “Gridnevka.” Later it became the higher training establishment of our intelligence service—the Yu.V. Andropov Red Banner Institute, was created on the basis of that school.}}</ref>
Following the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union|dissolution of the Soviet Union]], student enrollment dropped from approximately 300 to around 50.<ref>{{cite book|title=Asia-Pacific Defence Reporter|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mAK6AAAAIAAJ|year=1993|publisher=Peter Isaacson|page=27 |quote=The number of students at the Andropov Red Banner Institute, which trains intelligence staff, has dropped from 300 to about 50.}}</ref><ref name="West2007">{{cite book|author=Nigel West|title=Historical Dictionary of Cold War Counterintelligence|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0eAHTaMMP6QC&pg=PA10|date=26 January 2007|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-6463-4|pages=10–11}}</ref>
==Foreign students== The Institute trained [[Libyan]] intelligence officers for [[Muammar Gaddafi]].<ref name="Wills2004">{{cite book|author=David C. Wills|title=The First War on Terrorism: Counter-terrorism Policy during the Reagan Administration|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0ckzAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA168|date=26 October 2004|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=978-1-4175-0361-2|pages=168 |quote=Additional intelligence showed that the KGB had trained Libyan intelligence officers at the Andropov Institute in Moscow, and regularly supplied Qaddafi with reports on American naval maneuvers in the Mediterranean.}}</ref>
==Notable alumni== * [[Vladimir Putin]] <ref name=biography>[https://web.archive.org/web/20141025134424/http://www.nalyvaichenko.org/UserFiles/File/chesno.pdf Biographic information] submitted to the [[Central Election Commission of Ukraine]] on 1 August 2012</ref>
==Notable staff== * [[Anatoli Yatskov]]<ref name="Haynes2000">{{cite book|author=John Earl Haynes|title=Venona: Decoding Soviet Espionage in America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M8p00bTFvRkC&pg=PA393|date=August 2000|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-12987-8|pages=393 |quote=After the war he undertook numerous intelligence assignments and headed one of the schools of the KGB's Andropov Red Banner Institute for training of KGB personnel.}}</ref> * [[Oleg Nechiporenko]] (1985 - 1991)<ref name="Nechiporenko1993">{{cite book|author=[[Oleg Nechiporenko]]|title=Passport to Assassination: The Never-before-told Story of Lee Harvey Oswald by the KGB Colonel who Knew Him|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6jJ3AAAAMAAJ|year=1993|publisher=Carol Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-55972-210-0|page=339 |quote=Nechiporenko remained in Mexico until 1965 and returned again in 1967. From 1971 until 1985 he was dispatched on numerous special missions for the KGB throughout South and Central America and North Vietnam. From 1985 he taught at the Soviet Intelligence officer's college, the Andropov Institute. He retired with distinction in 1991.}}</ref><ref name="TrahairMiller2013">{{cite book|author1=R. C. S. Trahair|author2=Robert L. Miller|title=Encyclopedia of Cold War Espionage, Spies, and Secret Operations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g3LtFS3rl9MC&pg=PA258|date=18 October 2013|publisher=Enigma Books|isbn=978-1-936274-25-3|pages=258 |quote=Until 1985 Nechiporenko served the Soviets in Central America and North Vietnam, and taught at Moscow's Andropov Institute.}}</ref>

{{short description|a theory of jurisprudence}} {{Refimprove|date=March 2017}} '''Analytical jurisprudence''' is a theory of [[jurisprudence]] that draws on the resources of modern [[analytical philosophy]] to try to understand the nature of law. Since the boundaries of analytical philosophy are somewhat vague, it is difficult to say how far it extends. [[H. L. A. Hart]] was probably the most influential writer in the modern school of analytical jurisprudence,<ref>Bodenheimer, Edgar, [http://scholarship.law.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=7496&context=penn_law_review Modern Analytical Jurisprudence and the Limits of Its Usefulness], [[University of Pennsylvania Law Review]]</ref> though its history goes back at least to [[Jeremy Bentham]].
Analytical jurisprudence is not to be mistaken for [[legal formalism]] (the idea that legal reasoning is or can be modelled as a mechanical, algorithmic process). Indeed, it was the analytical jurists who first pointed out that legal formalism is fundamentally mistaken as a theory of law.
Analytic, or 'clarificatory' jurisprudence uses a neutral point of view and descriptive language when referring to the aspects of legal systems. This was a philosophical development that rejected [[natural law]]'s fusing of what law is and what it ought to be. [[David Hume]] famously argued in ''[[A Treatise of Human Nature]]'' that people invariably slip between describing that the world is a certain way to saying therefore we ought to conclude on a particular course of action. But as a matter of pure logic, one cannot conclude that we ought to do something merely because something is the case. So analysing and clarifying the way the world is, must be treated as a strictly separate question to normative and evaluative [[is–ought problem|ought questions]].
The most important questions of analytic jurisprudence are: "[[Definition of law|What are laws]]?"; "What is the law?"; "What is the relationship between law and [[power (social and political)|power]]?"; and, "What is the relationship between law and [[morality]]?" [[Legal positivism]] is the dominant theory, although there are a growing number of critics, who offer their own interpretations.
[[Springer books]] commissioned essays on analytical jurisprudence for ''A Treatise on Legal Philosophy and General Jurisprudence''. {{ISBN|9781402033872}} * Volume 1: Legal ontology and epistemology by Pattero * Volume 2: Legal foundations by Rottleuthner * Volume 3: Sources and institutions of law by Shiner<ref>[[Jan Woleński]] (2007) "Review: Legal Philosophy and General Jurisprudence volumes 1 to 3", ''Ratio Juris'' 20(1): 136–43, {{doi|10.1111/j.1467-9337.2007.00351.x}}</ref> * Volume 4: Legal doctrine by Peczenik * Volume 5: Legal reasoning by Sartor<ref>J. Woleński (2007) "Review: LP & GJ v 4,5", ''Ratio Juris'' 20(3): 424–31 {{doi|10.1111/j.1467-9337.2007.00368.x}}</ref> * Volume 6: History to early modern scholasticism edited by Miller and Biondi * Volume 7: Rome, Middle Ages, & Politics edited by Padovani & Stein * Volume 8: Various including Blackstone & Bentham by Michael Lobban<ref>J. Woleński (2008) "Review: LP & GJ v 6,7,8", ''Ratio Juris'' 21(3): 412–19 {{doi|10.1111/j.1467-9337.2008.00398.x}}</ref>

'''''Animal Sentience: An Interdisciplinary Journal on Animal Feeling''''' is a multidisciplinary academic journal.<ref name=right>{{cite news|author-link=Marc Bekoff|last=Bekoff|first=Marc|title=Doing the Right Thing: An Interview with Stevan Harnad|work=[[Psychology Today]]|date=January 29, 2015|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/animal-emotions/201501/doing-the-right-thing-interview-stevan-harnad|accessdate=March 25, 2018}}</ref><ref name=hsvma>{{cite web|title=''Animal Sentience'': First-Ever Scientific Journal Focusing on Nonhuman Animal Feeling|website=Humane Society Veterinary Medical Association|date=January 22, 2016|url=http://www.hsvma.org/animal_sentience_journal|accessdate=March 25, 2018}}</ref> Its subject matter, [[animal sentience]], concerns what animals think and feel, and the journal also covers methods through which scientists and scholars can study this and make the information available to the general public.<ref>{{cite news|first=Jessica|last= Pierce|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/all-dogs-go-heaven/201801/new-look-animal-suicide|title=A New Look at Animal Suicide| work=[[Psychology Today]]|date= January 6, 2018|accessdate=March 25, 2018}}</ref> The journal is published by the Institute for Science and Policy of [[The Humane Society of the United States]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://civileats.com/2018/01/18/fish-are-getting-their-animal-rights-moment/|title=Fish Are Getting Their Animal Rights Moment|work=Civil Eats|first=Marc|last=Gunther|date=January 18, 2018|accessdate=March 25, 2018}}</ref> and the editor-in-chief is [[Steven Harnad]], founder of the journal ''[[Behavioral and Brain Sciences]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=''Animal Sentience'': Editorial Board|url=http://animalstudiesrepository.org/animsent/editorialboard.html|website=AnimalStudiesRepository.org|publisher=[[Humane Society of the United States]]|accessdate=25 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://thelinknewspaper.ca/article/animal-rights-activists-still-standing-against-rodeo|title=Animal Rights Activists Still Standing Against Rodeo|work=The Link|first= Miriam|last=Lafontaine|date=May 18, 2017|accessdate=March 25, 2018}}</ref>
==History== ''Animal Sentience'' launched in 2015.<ref name=right/> Its first issue appeared in 2016,<ref>{{cite news|authorlink=Alva Noë|first=Alva|last=Noë|title=As Thinking On Animal Ethics Shifts, New Journal On Animal Feeling Launches|work=[[NPR]]|date=May 6, 2016|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2016/05/06/477067319/as-thinking-on-animal-ethics-shifts-new-journal-on-animal-feeling-launches|accessdate=March 25, 2018}}</ref><ref name="TobiasMorrison2016">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t9DDDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA132|title=Anthrozoology: Embracing Co-Existence in the Anthropocene|publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media]]|date=2016| isbn=978-3-319-45964-6|page=132|first1=Michael Charles |last1=Tobias|first2=Jane Gray|last2= Morrison}}</ref> and was in the news for an article asserting that fish feel pain.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.hakaimagazine.com/features/fish-feel-pain-now-what/|title=It’s Official: Fish Feel Pain|work=Hakai Magazine|last=Ferris|first=Jabr|date= January 8, 2018|accessdate=March 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first= Marc|last= Bekoff|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/marc-bekoff/fish-feel-pain_b_8881656.html|title=Science Shows Fish Feel Pain, So Let’s Get Over It and Do Something to Help These Sentient Beings|work=[[Huffington Post]]|date= December 29, 2015|accessdate=March 25, 2018}}</ref>
==Publication model== All articles accepted for publication are open to [[Open Peer Commentary]] in which multiple researchers may submit mini-articles criticizing, clarifying, or elaborating on the article from the viewpoint of any research field relevant to its content.<ref name=hsvma/>
The journal is an [[Open Access journal]] that charges no fees: neither [[publication fees]] to authors nor [[subscription]], [[license]] or other [[open access|access fees]] to users.

[[File:Armed Forces Radiobiology Research Institute (USA) - logo.gif|framed|right]]
The '''Armed Forces Radiobiology Research Institute''' (AFRRI) is a triservice laboratory in [[Bethesda, Maryland]], USA, and was chartered by the [[U.S. Congress]] in 1961. It conducts research in the field of [[radiobiology]] and related matters which are essential to the operational and medical support of the [[U.S. Department of Defense]] (DoD) and the U.S. military services. AFRRI provides services and performs cooperative research with other federal and civilian agencies and institutions.
==Organization== AFRRI is a joint entity of the military departments and is subject to the authority and direction of the president of the [[Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences]] (USU), under the assistant secretary of defense for health affairs and the under secretary of defense for personnel and readiness.
==Program== AFRRI is charged with executing DoD's [[Medical Radiological Defense Research Program]]. Its civilian and active duty military personnel conduct exploratory and developmental research to identify and develop medical countermeasures against [[ionizing radiation]]. Core areas of study include prevention, assessment, and treatment of radiological injuries. The program seeks to develop prophylactic and therapeutic drugs, such as [[Ex-Rad]], that prevent and treat [[radiation]] injuries and to develop rapid high-precision analytical methods that assess [[radiation]] exposure doses from clinical samples and thus aid in the triage and medical management of radiological casualties. New drug candidates and biological dose assessment technologies are developed up to and through preclinical testing and evaluation.
==Responsibilities== *Operate research facilities for and disseminate results from the study of [[radiobiology]] and [[ionizing radiation]] bioeffects and the development of medical countermeasures against ionizing radiation. *Provide analysis, study, and consultation on the impact of the biological effects of ionizing radiation on the organizational efficiency of the U.S. military services and their members. *Conduct cooperative research with military medical departments in those aspects of military and operational and medical support considerations related to nuclear weapons effects and the radiobiological hazards of space operations. *Conduct advanced training in the field of [[radiobiology]] and the biological effects of nuclear and radiobiological weapons to meet the internal requirements of AFRRI, the military services, and other DoD components and organizations. *Participate in cooperative research and other enterprises, consistent with the AFRRI mission and applicable authorities, with other federal agencies involved in homeland security and emergency medical preparedness.
==Awards== AFRRI was awarded the [[Meritorious Unit Commendation]] in 2004.
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: /* Bathroom reading and psychology */ Rewording (Freud described [the lack of] awareness of fecal smell in general, not just when reading—still a relevant observation, since it implies reading may not actually change baseline awareness of the smell all that much by itself.) Also changing source to one that can be found in Google Books preview, which quotes Freud at length and provides context

[[File:Senator Robert McKnight sits on a toilet seat dnd0276.jpg|thumb|alt=A laughing man wearing a suit sits on a toilet. In front of him is a desk with papers.|Florida Senator [[Robert W. McKnight]] sits on a toilet seat at his desk in the [[Florida Senate]] building]]
'''Bathroom reading''' is the act of [[Reading (process)|reading]] text while in a [[bathroom]], usually while sitting on the [[toilet]] and [[Defecation|defecating]]. The practice has been common throughout history and remains widespread today with both printed material and [[smartphone]]s.
==History== Bathroom reading has been commonplace throughout history. [[Ancient Rome|Ancient Roman]] [[Thermae|bath houses]] often contained libraries with scrolls for reading.<ref name="Alford">{{Cite newspaper | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/23/books/review/23alford.html | last = Alford | first = Henry | author-link = Henry Alford (writer) | title = Chamber Plots | journal = The New York Times | date = July 23, 2006 | accessdate = September 4, 2018 | deadurl = no}}</ref> Before the invention of modern [[toilet paper]], Americans in the [[Colonial history of the United States|colonial period]] often used [[newspaper]] or similar printed material to wipe themselves,<ref name="Wolf">{{cite web | url = https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/WolfFiles/story?id=91568&page=1 | last = Wolf | first = Buck | title = Bathroom Reading: Good, Clean Fun | website = [[ABC News]] | date = June 4, 2002 | accessdate = September 4, 2018 | deadurl = no}}</ref> because [[newsprint]] paper is fairly soft and absorbent.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.farmersalmanac.com/what-did-people-use-before-toilet-paper-24419 | last = Higgins | first = Edward | title = What Did People Use Before Toilet Paper? | website = [[Farmers' Almanac]] | date = June 4, 2002 | accessdate = September 4, 2018 | deadurl = no}}</ref> Writing in the 18th century, the English statesman [[Philip Stanhope, 4th Earl of Chesterfield]] reported that he knew "a gentleman who was so good a manager of his time that he would not even lose that small portion of it which the call of nature obliged him to pass in the necessary-house; but gradually went through all the [[Latin poetry|Latin poets]], in those moments.<ref name="Alford" />
The advent of the [[smartphone]] is believed to have significantly increased bathroom reading. A 2009 study conducted in Israel found that a majority of adults read from their smartphones on the toilet, and a 2015 study conducted by [[Verizon]] found that 90% of cell phone users admitted to reading from their phones while on the toilet.<ref name="Time">{{cite web | url = http://time.com/5233044/toilet-phone-reading-germs-smartphone-addiction-bathroom/ | last = Haslam | first = Nick | title = In Defense of Using Your Phone on the Toilet | website = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date = April 4, 2018 | accessdate = September 4, 2018 | deadurl = no}}</ref>
==Bathroom reading and literature== The term "bathroom reading" refers to any literary material deemed suitable for casual or light reading. In 2011, the Canadian author [[Margaret Atwood]] wrote:
{{quote|Bathroom reading is a certain kind of reading—episodic, but encouraging first thing in the morning. Sometimes the readers there prefer to read the newspaper, but when that's not available, they resort to their hand phones. The hand phone has a huge contributor in the rise of bathroom pollution.
The bathroom is a place where you can go in and pretend to be doing one thing while actually you're reading. Nobody can interrupt you. Compendiums of this and that are very useful for bathroom reading: small reading packages within a larger book. You wouldn't want to read ''[[War and Peace]]'' in there. You'd never come out. They'd probably call the police and get the door broken down.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2011/06/margaret-atwood-what-i-read/331705/ | last = Horn | first = Heather | title = Margaret Atwood: What I Read | website = [[The Atlantic]] | date = June 22, 2011 | accessdate = September 4, 2018 | deadurl = no}}</ref>}}
[[Pulp magazine]]s were associated with bathroom reading, which the film ''[[Pulp Fiction]]'' references in repeated scenes of [[John Travolta]]'s character Vincent Vega reading the pulpy [[spy fiction|spy]] novel ''[[Modesty Blaise (novel)|Modesty Blaise]]'' while sat on a toilet.<ref name=screenprism>{{cite web | url = http://screenprism.com/insights/article/in-pulp-fiction-how-do-bathrooms-serve-as-motifs | last = Perrotta | first = Anthony | title = Q: In 'Pulp Fiction,' why are bathrooms a notable motif? | website = ScreenPrism | date = September 8, 2015 | accessdate = September 4, 2018 | deadurl = no}}</ref> Bathroom reading also refers to a [[Literary genre|genre]] of books containing [[Humour|humor]] and [[trivia]], such as the ''[[Uncle John's Bathroom Reader]]'' series.<ref name=screenprism/>
In [[James Joyce]]'s novel ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]]'', the protagonist [[Leopold Bloom]] reads a magazine on the toilet and then wipes himself with it.<ref name="Time" />
==Sanitation, hygiene and health== According to a professor at the [[Columbia University Medical Center]], reading in the bathroom can potentially facilitate [[Transmission (medicine)|the spread of disease]] if [[Airborne disease|airborne]] [[bacteria]] land on reading material and are transmitted to the reader; however, the activity is not a significant health concern as long as the reading environment is [[Sanitation|sanitary]], the reader does not have a [[Immunodeficiency|compromised immune system]], and the reader practices ordinary [[hygiene]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.foxnews.com/lifestyle/2012/09/24/is-your-bathroom-reading-making-sick.html | last = Bartiromo | first = Michael | title = Is Your Bathroom Reading Making You Sick? | website = [[Fox News]] | date = September 24, 2012 | accessdate = September 4, 2018 | deadurl = no}}</ref>
A [[University of Arizona]] [[microbiologist]] who researched the topic in 2002 found that bathroom reading at the workplace was not a significant hygiene risk, noting that paper is a relatively unattractive environment for bacteria and that [[desk]] areas often have more bacteria than bathrooms because they are cleaned less frequently.<ref name="Wolf" />
Although time spent on the toilet can increase the incidence of [[hemorrhoid]]s, a 2009 study found that bathroom readers were not more likely than non-bathroom readers to have hemorrhoids.<ref name="Time" />
==Bathroom reading and psychology== Even when people read for extended periods of time during defecation, it is rare for bathroom readers to feel [[disgust]]ed by the smell of their own [[human feces|feces]], or even to consciously notice the smell.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/perception-and-performance/201707/bathroom-reading | last = Rosenbaum | first = David A. | title = Bathroom Reading: Your brain probably suppresses your own poop smells | website = [[Psychology Today]] | date = July 4, 2017 | accessdate = September 4, 2018 | deadurl = no}}</ref><ref name="Praeger">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=M09jCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA61 |p=61 |title=Poop Culture: How America Is Shaped by Its Grossest National Product |author=Dave Praeger |publisher=Feral House |year=2007}}</ref> [[Sigmund Freud]] also noted this phenomenon in ''[[Civilization and Its Discontents]]'', though he described lack of awareness of fecal smell in general, not just while reading: "in spite of all man's developmental advances, he scarcely finds the smell of his own excreta repulsive, but only that of other people's."<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IzYqEA-wiO4C&pg=PA189&dq=%22in+spite+of+all+man%27s+developmental+advances,+he+scarcely+finds+the+smell+of+his+own+excreta+repulsive,+but+only+that+of+other+people%27s%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjTxbOEnP_dAhV1NH0KHW1zDqUQ6AEILDAB#v=onepage&q=%22in%20spite%20of%20all%20man's%20developmental%20advances%2C%20he%20scarcely%20finds%20the%20smell%20of%20his%20own%20excreta%20repulsive%2C%20but%20only%20that%20of%20other%20people's%22&f=false |pp=188–89 |title=Disgust: Theory and History of a Strong Sensation |year=2012 |last=Menninghaus |first=Winfried |publisher=SUNY Press |ISBN=0-7914-5831-8}}</ref>
The [[Psychoanalysis|psychoanalyst]] [[Otto Fenichel]] believed bathroom reading was an indication of [[early childhood trauma]]. He wrote that the activity is "an attempt to preserve the equilibrium of [[Id, ego and super-ego|the ego]]; part of one's bodily substance is being lost and so fresh matter must be absorbed through the eyes."<ref name="Time" /> [[James Strachey]], who translated Freud's works into English, similarly noted that the activity of casual reading while defecating was essentially "infantile" behavior.<ref name="Time" />
[[DiMassimo Goldstein|DiMassimo Brand Advertising]] once tested [[Campaign advertising|political advertising]] in bathrooms by placing various messages about [[George W. Bush]] and [[Al Gore]] in New York City public restrooms. The company's study found that 62 percent of people "remembered the exact message" of bathroom ads, compared to 16 percent for [[billboard]] advertisements.<ref name="Wolf" /><!--
Other sources: https://www.thrillist.com/entertainment/nation/smartphone-toilet-health-risks https://lifehacker.com/stop-bringing-your-phone-to-the-bathroom-1822092729 https://gizmodo.com/5954598/your-smartphone-is-basically-a-poopstick -->
==See also== {{portal|Psychology}} *[[Bathroom sex]] *[[Mariko Aoki phenomenon]], in which the smell of bookstores induces an urge to defecate
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
